Well, hm.  No, that's not it.  That' sjust the source.  One sec.

sicking: did anybody tell you yet about the prize for filing bug but 10000?
MikeSmith: no?! What do I win? A brand new car? $10000000 from dead Nigerian prince? A years supply of viagra?
you won editorship of the WebIDL spec
so, congratulations!
pats sicking on the back
hahaha
runs
heh
maybe we should rename that spec Hot Potato

or XBL3...
re: CSS I was told UAs can’t drop vendor prefixes until the relevant spec goes CR. Given border-radius on Opera even though CSS3 Backgrounds is still Working Draft, that’s wrong, no?
Backgrounds went CR for a short time.
And then we pulled it back to make some useful changes.
It should be back to Last Call any time now, too.
TabAtkins: aaah, that explains it. so regarding adding non-prefixed versions to ‘future-proof’ (like for transitions), is that bad? (given the spec could change etc)
Yes and no.  It's good, and it's bad, and it's good and bad to do the opposite.
lol
thanks for your definitive answer :)
If you put in unprefixed versions, figuring that they won't change, you create some pressure to not change it, since you have deployed content that won't be compatible.
(it certainly covered all the bases)
But if you don't, then you make it more painful to drop prefixed versions, since you might not update your site to use the unprefixed one.
So, shrug?
I use unprefixed, but only if I'm using the property in a simple enough manner that I'm confident it won't change.
yeah, I personally work on the expectation that most specs won’t change significantly, and if there is a major change it’ll be something I notice and then go fix
i use prefixes. after all, that is what they are for.
there’s no site (that I know of) tracking what browsers are or have been using prefixes, so it’s hard to keep on top of adding unprefixed versions in
boblet, progressive degradation or how it is called ;)
make your site work without fancy backgrounds, problem solved
erlehmann: graceful degredation ;-)
but the unprefixed versions could be seen as progressive enhancement (for the glorious future of unprefixed support)
erlehmann: what if the purpose of your site is two demonstrate fancy backgrounds?
i would always settle for one fancy background, comrade.
you sound like a possible appreciator of the "wabi sabi" aesthetic
which, btw and unfortunately, most Japanese websites demonstrate completely the opposite of the wabi-sabi aesthetic
with some exceptions
like the sites that boblet creates in Japan
which are much more wabi and sabi
wat
MikeSmith: i like to think of them as more wasabi
boblet: please make em more like yuzu koshou
MikeSmith: ooh man! I’m so addicted to that stuff atm. although it prolly should be called yuzu shio huh

I'm looking for more stuff to add to the rationale document - if anyone has any ideas please let me know

most of the commit descriptions don't provide much rationale
MikeSmith, I'm looking for recent contecious decisions that have some kind of trail on the mailing list
just recent ones?
*contentious
MikeSmith, older ones are OK as well
anything that is contentious and needs to be documented ;)
for some recent ones, reviewing W3C bugzilla might help
http://www.w3.org/Bugs/Public/buglist.cgi?cmdtype=runnamed&namedcmd=HTML%20WG%20issues
and for older ones, going back through the whatwg archives and checking Hixie messages
to find ones where he indicates that he's made a change to the spec
MikeSmith, anything specific ?
variable: nothing specific
http://lists.whatwg.org/htdig.cgi/whatwg-whatwg.org/
you may find there is some pattern to the messages from Hixie
something in the subject line, I dunno

MikeSmith, I've been following the mailing list - looking for questions where people ask or answer why certain things are the case. But I can't go over everything -  hence fishing for more things to add
going back through Mark Pilgrim's This Week in HTML5 postings might actually be the best way

and his "What's Next" ones

since 5105

oh, maybe it's the caching

is the 'next' button screwing things up?
no
well, I don't think so
you think?
i figured maybe someone clicked 'next' and it gave 'no result' and then 'no result' was cached
hmm
I don't think so

ok
this is gonna take ages
oh great
the cache was what made some of it still work
lol
god dammit
hides
hm....working now, it seems
it seems that I will have to remove the context option as the external diff program caused the whole thing to break down
sorry hsivonen
though when I looked through the cache it seems nobody was really using that anyway
for those keeping score...ff trunk now has support for figure/figcaption and mark
you can keep score here: http://wiki.whatwg.org/wiki/Implementations_in_Web_browsers
haven't checked to see whether special width stuff for figures works right
thanks a-ja, all trackers appear to be fully functioning again
and we got rid of a feature in the process
always a good thing
yeah...looks good from here,too
Nice IE9 PP3 improves the DOM namespace compliance with HTML and SVG nodes
notices "The new rgba() color notation works in quirks, 7, and 8 document modes. In future versions of IE9, this syntax will only apply in the browser's most standard mode." in the relnotes
i wonder if ie10 will have yet another mode
when quirks mode gets standardized the house of cards will collapse
annevk: why? they can just choose to ignore the quirks mode spec
from the IE blog
"We encourage the other browser vendors to help the W3C finish the HTML5 specification by providing additional tests to the official HTML5 testing task force."
zcorpan_, it seems they haven't been able to ignore most other specs
Yeah, we need some more work on the testsuite
i wonder if the tests they submit is all tests they have
I have not been impressed with the quality or number of the tests submitted so far
zcorpan_: I doubt it
I assume they vet tests that they submit to make sure they don't fail too many
so on the one hand the quality of the tests Microsoft has submitted are quite poor but on the other hand they have actually submitted tests
it's a pretty big shift in the Web that now the latest preview releases of all top 5 browsers can play YouTube videos without Flash
Yeah
annevk: ^
annevk: Don't really know how to encourage others to submit though
jgraham: lead by example?
zcorpan_: Yeah, Opera need to do better too
jgraham, we could submit the html5lib tests and surrounding framework I suppose
jgraham, is the i
licensing compatible?
annevk: I think so
the thing is, each time we add new tests we would then have to update a number of repositories :/
I am happy for the W3C copy to be the official home for html5lib tests
Assuming that they don't abuse that position
roc: thanks -- I had been wondering what he might be working on
hey krijnh is back
annevk: I have a better HTML harness for the html5lib tests
also
jgraham, that moves it from MIT to BSD

OK , I've contributed to the list and such and the only responses I've received is that it is a good idea, and in other venues the only opposition has been that since we have not done it we should not.
jgraham, so new tests only contributed to the W3C cannot be moved back?
https://twitter.com/mhausenblas/status/16912067471
Hmm, it depends if you think the BSD license is a problem or not I guess
yes, hsivonen? :)
We should IMHO integrate XSL with HTML5 with the element level attributes XML/XSL and perhaps include an XML attribute
In the short term the next thing that should be submitted is the canvas testsuite
Include an XML element I meant
On consideration, I think it would be easiest if Philip` did that, assuming he is willing
Be it twitter,fox news , or many other venues , XML is totally out there, Having an XML and XSL attributes simply makes sense , and an XML attribute a natural extension
I could certainly fake these things in javascript , but given the volume of traffic , why make what should be in the HTML5 dialect a vendor specific javascript happening?
I know that some consider CSS , or other corners of web development not worth their time, but XML/XSL is totally worth the effort
Anything in HTML5 that integrates other w3.org specs is worth at least vigorous debate

Be it the weather, stocks, ebay,twitter, the daily news , or an appointment calender or hundreds of other situations , ignoring the thought of XML/XSL attributes and possibly an XML element is simply foolish
you may have missed it, but we're not big believers in this XML thing
it's sort of the reason we started doing HTML5
I know , not believing in XML (HTML4, HTML5 etc) might be an issue
having said that, there's XML and XSLT APIs available, so if people want it they can easily use them together
compared to DOM manipulation though their usage is negligible

Your so full of excuses my friend. There has never been a truly valid recognition of any standard that was not already strongly in ones wallet. I'm championing something that might not be your thought of today but actually respects the standards that would be in your wallet tomarrow.
YOu know I have no idea what you just said
it's not about recognition, it's about adoption
Why should I ignore a standard that saves copious bandwidth, increases productivity and profit, just because somebody might not at first glance understand it
if something is clearly in use patterns emerge and simplifications can be made
e.g. lots of sites have a date picker, so we can assume <input type=date> will be useful to them
Slavery of black people was a standard , but did not reflect the future , but I guess I should use your claim to justify same
jaja and hitler was against smoking, so being against smoking is evil
geez
input type=date seems fine to me as the input is asked often enough and could benefit from standardization
Smoking is a personal decision and not something related to standards , but given such arguments I can see the value in your position (NOT)
was wondering when Godwin would appear :)
Give me your argument against XML/XSL options!
I can start the for arguments with the many many many services offering XML outputs and that XSL options allow all them XML outputs to be integrated into any presentation
Your against arguments start with ......?
krijnh: logs aren't responding. maybe DNS out of sync again?
hsivonen: Yeah, he said so earlier
As I suspected, either you have no valid argument against the proposal or your argument requires so much encapsulation as to both take to much time to respond and or not even be valid
Dashiva^2: OK
XML is a very common method of interaction and XSL a very free form method of presentation and really should be as a matter of w3.org interoperability be given a fair hearing
XSL is but the flip side of CSS
They have been given a fair hearing, look at actual usage
zcorpan_: Ping
Philip`: pong

drclue: The valid argument is "very few people use XSLT. Implementors would likely not implement more XSLT features. The functionality you want can be trivially written in javascript. Ergo your proposal is not worth standardising until several of these things change"
zcorpan_: Could you send the IE9 results as an attachment or something? I don't know how to easily fix the linewrapping in the email
The actual usage of XSL has not been held up by it's value but rather it's implementation and standard. I could most easily site the same excuses for / against the deployment of the video element
Can you cite an excuse against  the XSL that has any more validity than one might have against the video element?
People code non-standard and non-cross-browser-compatible features without restraint if they actually want them
Video, you may have noticed, was rather popular before <video> was added
Again , can you cite a reason against the support of the w3.org standard XSL that would not apply to the video element?
drclue: (a clue: the words "w3.org standard" don't magically win arguments here)
drclue: lolcats with XSL is harder than with video
drclue: most W3C standards are not implemented in browsers
So your argument would be like those that used bgcolor="" as opposed to those that used the CSS equivalent
XSL is implemented in all major and most minor browsers
So there's no problem
The feature already exists
The exploitation of the feature is not implemented , but the proposed standard would make it more mainstream
if it was desired it would be mainstream, through workarounds
see video
see <input type=date>
drclue: if the usage of the current JS APIs for XSLT become ridiculously mainstream, then, maybe, there's a reason to provide a declatative way
see what went before Web Sockets
Someone ought to make an XSLT Compact Syntax

Server load would be greatly reduced , developer coding would be greatly reduced. To say that because one has not added something to the spec is a reason not to add it is so lame as to cause me to choke on the laughter
drclue: http://wiki.whatwg.org/wiki/FAQ#Is_there_a_process_for_adding_new_features_to_a_specification.3F
Yippie skippy , good try , not playing here
I get the feeling drclue isn't actually reading what anyone else is writing
I read lots of things , but perhaps not always what you want me to read or in the case of reading same not always agreeing
It's like having mookid back
I thought they were the same person?
Oh well that's why then
So in lue of a position you write what you do. Obviously you have no validity to your position
One should argue their position , not play junior highschool kid games
we did plenty to explain our position
Plese cite your valid arguments
please read what we wrote
I miss mookid
-> lunch
I've been reading what you have all written and it sounds like a bunch of kids at lunch
drclue: I strongly recommend you look into content negotation
lol
annevk, when quirks mode gets standardized, I'm betting IE9 will support it in standards mode (ironically), but keep some or all of the old modes for IE-specific code paths that still aren't updated.
zcorpan_: http://philip.html5.org/tests/canvas/suite/tests/results.html - thanks
So you think that citing "content negotiation" is supposed to scare me?
roc: ^
thanks
drclue, do you think repeated claims that we're all ignoring you and not making any arguments, rather than actually addressing the arguments, is going to persuade us?
also fixed a few test bugs but didn't update the results so they don't quite match any more
AryehGregor: how could they implement quirks mode in standards mode? that doesn't make any sense
You can't make browser implementers implement what you want just by putting it in a spec.  If you can't convince them of your argument, there's no point in proceeding.
people on my blog keep annoying me by claiming Mozilla is evil for not implementing every W3C REC

I don't think that closed minds ignoring years of w3.org efforts are easily persuaded as those ignoring such efforts need to take responsibility for their actions  which just may be impossible for them to do
points to http://spreadsheets.google.com/ccc?key=0AtnDcoh7FXfAdEFuWVlVVDZTVkFWdnRqaWFGMzNYM3c&hl=en

zcorpan_, I mean that someone will spec the behavior other browsers use for choosing quirks mode, and will spec quirks mode itself, but IE will still let you explicitly opt out of that and rely on blacklists and other heuristics.
drclue, then I guess you're out of luck.  Try making your own web browser, I guess.
Or get a law passed.
Not much else for you to do about it.
@AryehGregor:   There indeed is not much to actually implement as all the code is already in the browsers , even old IE
roc: You don't implement Web Services Choreography Description Language?! Clear evil.
The only fight here is should we leverage what is in all browsers to the benefit and advancement of the w3.org standards or simply talk shit for the sake of doing same
We've actually been removing support for W3C RECs. that makes us extra evil
Which ones?
(I guess that one is actually CR)
we had some support for SOAP, WSDL and XForms
all gone
The spec I suggest simply leverages code already implemented in ALL browsers
(I don't recall if they ever actually shipped in a browser)
oops
fat fingered
I think we've removed some XLink and XPointer stuff too but I don't remember the details
not sure if they're RECs
I *think* SOAP shipped in Netscape circa 2002 or 2003
Even IE6 (Gasp if I can even call that a browser) includes the support as does every piece of software we would actually call a browser
All I'm asking is to map a couple of att4ributes to the existing support in those browsers

drclue: you need to spec, implement and test all sorts of things starting with how this feature would integrate with the event loop and the progression of the parse of the document having those attributes
Of course there will always be those that would argue against light at sunrise, but asking to leverage what is already there is simply a no brainer
@hsivonen are you trying to make me laugh?
You are either trying to make me laugh or are trying to snow me
I've been at the keyboard probably longer than you have been alive
Chrome thinks software.hixie.ch is written in Irish Gaelic and offers to translate
source says lang="en"
I'm always bothered by spec that thinks in lang-en
and it offers to translate to Icelandic in a Finnish Chrome running on English Windows
FAIL
All machines , all languages and that is just a base line
hsivonen, I found that feature annoyingly unreliable.  I turned it off.
Obviously those developing something are apt to look at things through colored lenses
It would offer to translate all-ASCII Apache directory listings with English file names (I forget from what).
ASCII is biased too as some languages could not even fit in such a constrained space
It's a hard biscuit to think in broad terms , but it is required to do so as otherwise ones opinions are stupid
BRB
curiously, Google decides what UI language to install for Chrome from the IP address of the downloader
as opposed to making the installer stub sniff for the UI language of the OS, for example
You'd think that the latter would be more reliable . . . do they have data to the contrary?
Maybe it's less reliable in some places, but more reliable in others.
Maybe the application UI languages aren't a subset of the OS UI languages
i.e. the OS doesn't provide enough information to select one of the application languages
Philip`: that's possible but Finnish is a in the set of possible UI languages for Windows, Mac OS X and the top Linux distros
There are a lot of things in spec and implementation that bother me , like CSS trying to do display:table etc , but in the end I would rather allow a spec to over reach than to under reach

CSS was always to me style while HTML was structure but it is inevitable that any particular spec is going to reach as far as it can, which as far as I've seen has had more benefits than detractions as much as such detractions might at time disturb me
My basic hope is despite these excesses that each spec will in the course of things try to advance other specs in a mutual sort of way so that the entire spec ecosystem can grow together
admirable restraint, everyone

Of course I personally like all the pluses that XML/XSL has to offer an over strained system where the USA struggles to be even number 15 in the world. I try to advance the integration of this spec if for nothing else that it would allow number 15 in the world to function better than the current number one
@roc we were restrained?  Oh ya , I did not deploy my fusion weapon , shit , I guess your right :)
"I've been at the keyboard probably longer than you have been alive" -- I'm waiting for claims of axiomatic proofs now. This stuff is great :-)
@annevk: You have already had plenty of axiomatic proofs that XSL is worthless
No, those proofs are mostly empirical
Well, each would seem about as worthy an argument against XSL
There are many instances where I don't care for` a particular aspect of a w3.org standard , but none where I would simply because it was not my favorite argue against it in the face of it's benefits
AryehGregor, that seems pretty hard to do, but maybe to some extent
Those benefits are irrelevant until people show they care about them enough to use them

Well, I for one care about them enough to use them, and in the course of learning them consulted with scores of others who had learned them, just as when I learned CSS I lerned from many others in the face of at the time many nay sayers
There are many religions that object to vaccination , but I would be happy to disagree with them too
One could get a room full of folks to tell me that blacks should but shine shoes and I would disagree with them as well
Now if you would actually like to discuss the merits of the propositions as opposed to taking a bar stool poll , I'm more than up for that
Scores of people is not very much on internet scale
Well , are we talking the might of stagnation or the right of advancement?
We're talking about priorities, doing work on features that people actually want
Did people really WANT display:table vs element TABLE?
We're talking about spending time developing features that are likely to give the most benefit to the most people, based on evidence of how widespread are people demonstrating a need for that feature
Oh, like what Dashiva^2 said
display:table is sunk cost and anyway this is not the CSS WG

Well, I'm talking about the minimal investment to exploit functionality already built into every browser, to the benefit of all be they server side developers , client side developer , those paying for bandwidth etc.

drclue: Lots of people clearly wanted table-like layouts, and there were clear disadvantages to using <table> for layout (unmaintainable markup, can't adapt to widely varied display devices, etc), so there was a problem that needed to be solved
(display:table may or may not be an adequate solution to that problem)
The only benefit seems to be convenience
The feature set remains unchanged, and they are features people clearly do not care much about

@Philip I'm not arguing against the CSS attributes , as obviously you think they have value, but there was not a huge public demand for that feature , but rather a thought be the spec folks that it had value. Here I'm just saying that what I suggest has extreme value despite a public outcry for it's implementation. Specifications are often an act of consderation , not mob rule
If we had put everything to a bar stool vote , blacks would still be picking cotton
drclue: The intended approach for HTML5 has not been to look for demand expressed as public outcry, but to do research into what people do in practice
XSL saves server load , saves bandwidth , affords portability , scales between the ignorant and the savvy
drclue: You are the one who wants to force other people to follow your commands
Adjust your analogies accordingly
.. or are likely to be practicing when the features become available
which gives a more accurate indication of what problems people experience and are having to work around in more inefficient ways and are worth solving better
Well , maybe in practice one utilized selective questioning where they only aske the opinions of those on the bar stool next to them
I'm not forcing anyone to use XSL , but rather trying to make it available in a context beyond vendor specific javascript and http header mdness
XSL while supported in every browser, has been forced to contend with an implementation madness that has thwarted its value and for which I hope to provide a reasonable avenue of normalcy
Authors have coped with all kinds of madness. They would not be stopped if they actually wanted XSL.
annevk: IE9 PP3 bloated their Accept header.
I noticed that

I would not put an effort behind XSL if I did not believe it to have a very significant merit. XSL is an amazing specification both server side and client side , but alas the various implementations have made it almost impossible for the authors to deploy it. It was not simply a matter of author choice , but having to mess with apache add-type and a maze of mumbo jumbo to get browsers to properly deploy.
hsivonen, guess that might increase the amount of complaints a little, but I think we have a pretty strong case
@annevk , the only case you;ve made is to say you have one
I can say that XSL saves server load , saves bandwidth , reduces developer load and cite all day use cases for it that leverage existing sources all over the net
By simply adding an XSL and XSL attribute , I can immediately leverage many thousands of data sources
you can implement your proposal in a few lines of JavaScript as we have said several times so the arguments about load and saving bandwidth are bullshit
Fox,CNN,Twitter,Flicker, NOAA, and almost any other place of note
We could implement <video> in a few lines of javascript leveraging Flash , if all you have is that kind of argument
yes we could, but we do not want Flash
so we made <video>
Of course we would both stand up on each of our points citing the go do it in javascript thing as a bogus argument
and you still need JavaScript for <video> most of the time

IE blog says: "Note this video uses the HTML5 video tag (with the H.264 codec) if your browser supports it, and falls back to other methods otherwise. It’s a good example of same markup in action." I see "Install Microsoft Silverlight" but no video.
hsivonen: in Firefox?
But of course you need far less javascript , making things more standardized and robust. Same holds for XSL
hsivonen, yeah, "same markup" is such nonsense, but I lost the will to argue it long ago
Peter`: in Minefield with Flash Player installed
hsivonen: ah, then they're only supplying Silverlight fallbacks... makes sense (not)
I hate Flash too, but I really dislike arguments that hide behind such similar thinking as well

drclue, it's pretty clear people are willing to use JavaScript; if they want XSLT on the client in the way you suggest they can do that too, using some JavaScript; if they don't maybe they're not interested in XSLT
drclue, you could start implementing the "jQuery for XSLT" in Javascript and become famous!
I could use javascript to inflict flash video too , so lets ditch the lame arguments
XSL has true legitimate value , can you at least admit that , or do you have no honesty in this discussion at all?
lol
http://flashlab.com/html5/ is fun
LOL , I can too LOL at the idea that a quality w3.org specification can be given the short sheet by a wannbe specification that I also support
Why is it that one specification should disrespect another specification when the goal should be interoperability betyween all quality specs?
I think I'm going to stop feeding drclue now

I was generating HTML documentation of a file format based on a RelaxNG grammar, and wanted to include fragments of the grammar inside <pre> blocks in the output
I didn't give up, I checked various documentation and mailing lists and it appeared that the only solution was to manually write an XML serialiser
I use XSL to ease the development of documentation, and it works great for me. I'm able to embed HTML , XML , whatever I like
The real problem has been the odd ways in which XSL was deployed in the browsers. It made it really hard for folks to sort out the documentation
I like having a pattern-matching language that works cleanly over XML, but I'd like it more if there was extensive library support and if the syntax was much less verbose
One had to screw around with content-type headers that varied by browser and browser version and do so much screwing around before one could actually get to just doing XSL
The verbosity of the syntax was indeed annoying at first , but once I got the hang of it , the verbosity was no longer an issue
You must realize that most web developers will have given up before getting the hang of it at all, because of that

so from what I understand, async means: every function is run from top to down but the VM doesn't wait for them to complete their job?
and everything in JS works that way?
but otherwise it might not be too hard
taptapir: Every function call always runs to completion
The asynchronous bit is like in 'img.onload = function () { do something }' - that's just defining a function, not executing it, and then storing it somewhere (in the image) and carrying on
and some time after that script has finished, the browser will decide to call the function you stored in onload
JS itself doesn't do anything asynchronous - it just registers callbacks with the browser environment
effectively
hmm, I started some javascript books yesterday but none of them seems to mention the async nature of it. any good books/sources you can recommend?
doesn't know of any
Are you familiar with function pointers and callbacks in C?
yep
It's basically the same thing, except instead of using a function pointer like "&function_that_does_stuff" you can define it inline like "function() { do stuff }"
finally! thanks I get it a little bit better now
(You can also do "function do_stuff() { do stuff }; ... img.onload = do_stuff;" which is equivalent to "img.onload = function() { do stuff }")
yeah the first one is more C like :)
(except in the latter case the function can refer to variables in its container scope)
inline callbacks, that made sense.

taptapir: It could start to download in the background as soon as you set .src, though I don't know whether browsers will wait for the current script to return first

taptapir: onload will be called some time (probably immediately) after the image is downloaded and decoded and found to not have errors (else it'll call onerror instead, I think), and you can safely use the image for drawing in canvases etc after that
Philip`: so in this phase image is still not read to the memory right?
taptapir: Depends on what you mean by being in memory

taptapir: Browsers are free to do whatever optimisations they want in terms of caching data in memory, lazy decoding, etc, so you can never really know what they're doing - you just know whether or not it's safe to perform certain actions on images (like drawing them)
I mean, is the image data transferred to a buffer in the memory? or is it simply presented by something like file pointers in C?
Again, you don't know, because browsers are allowed to do what they want.  All you know is that certain actions are allowed at specific points.
It's been downloaded from the network (so you can use it immediately), but everything else is just implementation details that you shouldn't need to know about

annevk, the entire IE compatibility list thing can be fairly described as "hard to do", but IE has to do it anyway, since they have to deal with IE-only sites and IE-only code paths, so if they just implemented standards without compatibility they'd break.  (See: IE7.)
Philip`: you know I want to download my game assets before the game starts,  what I wonder is that if I do that will it fill up the memory?
lets say for 1000 images

Everyone else tends to get the same code paths in most cases, due to "develop your site for standards-compliant browsers, then fix for IE".  So they can converge on a common behavior without causing more bugs than they prevent, usually.
IE9's goal is explicitly to work with the same exact code everyone else gets, so hopefully IE10 won't need an IE9 compatibility mode.
taptapir: That's an implementation detail :-)

I think there would be a few steps required to make them into appropriate tests for a standards test suite:
1) ensure that everything tested is associated with specific conformance requirements in the spec
2) annotate the tests with the relevant conformance requirements
3) convert to whatever format the w3c wants them in

anyone got any opinions on how WebSRT cues should parse if they don't have a valid timestamp?
Drop on the floor?
the whole cue up to the next double blank line?
that's kinda what i figured should happen
other options are to just ignore the one line and try reading a timestamp from the next one
or to drop the whole file from there on
or to assume a timestamp of 0
or of equal to the last timestamp seen
I don't think anything that assumes a timestamp would be good.
Dropping the whole file is no good either, if the rest is properly formatted.
Ignoring just that line and trying the next sounds potentially cool.
So, one of those two.  Either skip the line, or skip everything until the next double blank line.
i guess skip the block is safest
